elements.content: The microporous β polymorph of the title compound has been prepared as a crystalline product by slow removal of the guest from the inclusion compound with methylene chloride, [CuL2]*2/3(CH2Cl2) (L is 1,1,1-trifluoro-5,5-dimethyl-5-methoxyacetylacetonate, {CF3COCHCOC(CH3)2OCH3}-). Collapse of the crystals of the β polymorph into the thermodynamically stable α form has been studied by visual observation and DSC calorimetry, the product exhibiting much higher kinetic stability than the polycrystalline samples prepared so far. The crystal structure of the β polymorph was determined by single-crystal XRD methods both at 293 and 173 K. The β polymorph retains the same 3D polymeric coordination framework as found previously in inclusion compounds of the complex. The structures of the β and α polymorphs are compared and the variation of the β matrix in a series of compounds was analyzed. The β framework described in this work seems to be the most flexible of all coordination polymers known so far, preserving its microporous structure upon guest exchange or removal; the complete range of change in molar volume observed for the matrix is 8.6%.

elements.content: The microporous β polymorph of the title compound has been prepared as bulk single crystals, revealing an enhanced kinetic stability. The β polymorph exhibits a 3D polymeric coordination framework with empty channels of 4.9 to 6.1 Å in diameter. The β framework exhibits a remarkable flexibility, expanding by more than 8% upon guest inclusion.

elements.content: The title complex [CuL2] (L = {CF3COCHCOC(CH3)2OCH3}-) assembles into a stable microporous framework and thus is an “organic zeolite”, a class of host materials heavily searched for but still very limited in number. A further advantage of the [CuL2] architecture is its remarkable flexibility and its response to external stimuli, attributes of “third generation microporous frameworks” as defined by Kitagawa & Kondo, a class of materials much expected to have considerable impact on future technology. Only a few host frameworks of this kind have been examined so far, and only the title compound has been confirmed to function cyclically as a first smart sorbent, a material whose sorption ability was triggered in situ by an operator.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The title complex [CuL2] (L = {CF3COCHCOC(CH3)2OCH3}-) assembles into a stable microporous framework and thus is an "organic zeolite", a class of host materials heavily searched for but still very limited in number. A further advantage of the [CuL2] architecture is its remarkable flexibility and its response to external stimuli, attributes of "third generation microporous frameworks" as defined by Kitagawa & Kondo, a class of materials much expected to have considerable impact on future technology. Only a few host frameworks of this kind have been examined so far, and only the title compound has been confirmed to function cyclically as a first smart sorbent, a material whose sorption ability was triggered in situ by an operator.

elements.content: The 3D assembly of [CuL2] complex units is known to give two polymorphs, the microporous one being referred to as the β form, whereas the other, dense polymorph is the α form. These designations come from classical ideas in clathrate chemistry which require the existence of at least two polymorphic forms of a host compound, α, which is denser and stable thermodynamically, and β, which is porous and stable kinetically, but acquiring thermodynamic stability only as the pores become filled with guest. Empty β forms have been isolated as metastable phases in several cases. The availability of both α and β forms of the same host has made it possible to compare their structures and stabilities by experiment, e.g., for hydroquinone, a Werner host, and a modified metal dibenzoylmethanate host. Both α and β forms of [CuL2] have been isolated. A crystal of the α form prepared by sublimation was studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In the past, the guest-free β form was prepared only as a powder by removing guest methyl bromide2,3 or methylene chloride4 from the channels of the β matrix. The β form is 1.3 kJ/mol less stable than the α form, and therefore eventually it collapses. The isolation of a single crystal of the β polymorph is quite desirable for testing its kinetic stability as well as for a full determination of its crystal structure to compare it with that of the α polymorph.

elements.content: The polymorphism of the [CuL2] complex is of special interest as molecular isomerization precedes the α ↔ β phase transformation. In the complex, the copper atom has square-planar coordination from two chelating ligands having asymmetric substituents. The α form contains both cis and trans [CuL2] units, whereas the β form contains only trans units. The idea of utilizing cis−trans molecular isomerism to enhance kinetic stability of metastable microporous frameworks is very attractive, but the [CuL2] complex of this work remains the only real example where this idea has been realized. Understanding this system could provide ideas on transferring molecular isomerism to other systems.

elements.content: Over 100 β inclusions of the [CuL2] host have been characterized, and several were studied by XRD methods. The detailed structure of the actual empty β matrix, which would be of great interest for the purpose of comparison, has not been studied as yet, as no single-crystal product has been isolated so far.

elements.content: In this work, the β form of the [CuL2] complex was prepared in single crystal form by decomposing an inclusion compound slowly enough so that the integrity of the single crystals was maintained. There are still very few examples of the preparation of organic or metal-organic microporous materials by “single-crystal-to-single-crystal” transition through desolvation.

elements.content: Preparation. A detailed description of the preparation of the [CuL2] complex, including the synthesis of the protonated 1,1,1-trifluoro-5,5-dimethyl-5-methoxyacetylacetone ligand, was given in our introductory paper. The α form (dense form) of the complex was used as a starting material for crystallization; it was purified additionally by two successive vacuum sublimations and tested for phase purity with powder XRD. Methylene chloride (Fisher, spectrophotometry, and gas chromatography grade purity, >99.9%) was distilled before the experiment. α-[CuL2] (1.025 g) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (6 g) in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was then loosely closed to allow the solvent to evaporate slowly. In a week, blue blocks or prisms of inclusion compound formed, presumably having the β-structure and an overall composition of [CuL2]*2/3(CH2Cl2). When the crystals were still wet with methylene chloride mother solution, the vial was tightly closed with a polyethylene stopper for methylene chloride to be removed very slowly from the crystal pore space. During the first month, the crystals became dry and the drying process was continued for one more month. Two and a half months after the experiment was started, the vial was opened and its content was evacuated for 20 h to a pressure <5 × 10-5 mmHg. The product was found to be the empty β form of [CuL2], as attested by other experiments reported in this work. The product was kept in air at room temperature. The first signs of transformation of the β polymorph back to the stable α form were observed after six months.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Preparation. A detailed description of the preparation of the [CuL2] complex, including the synthesis of the protonated 1,1,1-trifluoro-5,5-dimethyl-5-methoxyacetylacetone ligand, was given in our introductory paper. The α form (dense form) of the complex was used as a starting material for crystallization; it was purified additionally by two successive vacuum sublimations and tested for phase purity with powder XRD. Methylene chloride (Fisher, spectrophotometry, and gas chromatography grade purity, >99.9%) was distilled before the experiment. α-[CuL2] (1.025 g) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (6 g) in a 20 mL glass vial. The vial was then loosely closed to allow the solvent to evaporate slowly. In a week, blue blocks or prisms of inclusion compound formed, presumably having the β-structure and an overall composition of [CuL2]*2/3(CH2Cl2). When the crystals were still wet with methylene chloride mother solution, the vial was tightly closed with a polyethylene stopper for methylene chloride to be removed very slowly from the crystal pore space. During the first month, the crystals became dry and the drying process was continued for one more month. Two and a half months after the experiment was started, the vial was opened and its content was evacuated for 20 h to a pressure <5 × 10-5 mmHg. The product was found to be the empty β form of [CuL2], as attested by other experiments reported in this work. The product was kept in air at room temperature. The first signs of transformation of the β polymorph back to the stable α form were observed after six months.

elements.content: NMR Spectroscopy. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on a Bruker DRX-400 instrument for 0.05 M solutions of the polymorphs in deuterated chloroform or deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide. Assignments were based on data reported earlier2 and on changes resulting from intentional additions of methylene chloride. The complex protons appeared in the spectra as broad bands centered at ∼1.8 (>CH), 3.34 (CH3), 5.32 (OCH3) ppm for chloroform solutions and at ∼2.7 (CH3), ∼4.7 (OCH3) ppm for dimethyl sulfoxide solutions (>CH protons were not detectable in the latter case, presumably because of further broadening caused by hydrogen bonding). Methylene chloride protons showed as sharp lines at 5.32 and 5.74 ppm in chloroform and in dimethyl sulfoxide solutions, respectively.

elements.content: Differential Scanning Calorimetry. The experiments were run on a TA 2920 instrument utilizing a flow of nitrogen as the purge gas. A 5 to 15 mg amount of sample was heated in a sealed aluminum pan. Ground, crushed, or whole crystals were heated at a rate of 5 °C/min. The instrument was calibrated using indium.

elements.content: Powder XRD. Phase analyses were carried out on a Rigaku Geigerflex diffractometer with CoK α radiation (λ = 1.7902 Å) in the 5−30° 2θ range, with a 0.02° step scan with 1 or 2 s per step. A theoretical powder diffractogram was calculated from single-crystal XRD results.

elements.content: Single-Crystal XRD. All single-crystal XRD data obtained in this work were collected for the same single crystal (blue block, 0.3 0.3 0.4 mm) visually selected from a bulk β-[CuL2] product. The crystal was mounted on a glass fiber tip and installed on a Bruker SMART CCD X-ray diffractometer (MoK α radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å, graphite monochromator) equipped with a LT-2A low-temperature device. The first data set was collected at room temperature (ω scan mode over the θ range of 2−29°, coverage of the unique set of reflections >99%; −32/32, −32/32, −14/14 h,k,l-range). The crystal was then cooled in a flow of dry nitrogen at a rate of 4 deg/min down to 173 K, at which temperature the second data set was collected over a similar range.

elements.content: The integration of the diffraction profiles and an empirical absorption correction utilized the SAINT and SADABS routines, respectively, associated with the Bruker diffractometer. The unit cell parameters were calculated from the entire data sets. The structures referring to 293 and 173 K were solved (direct methods) and refined (difference Fourier synthesis) independently using the SHELXTL package. The structural refinement was performed on F 2 and applied to all data with positive intensities. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. An isotropic approximation and geometrical constraints were applied for a minor orientation of the disordered methoxy-iso-propyl fragment (at 293 K). Also, soft restraints were applied on geometry and thermal parameters of the disordered trifluoromethyl groups. Hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically with thermal factors 1.2 or 1.5 times greater than those for the adjacent carbon atoms. At 273 K, the greatest maximum on the residual density map was 0.25 e/Å3 and located inside a very wide part of the channel. Tentative modeling of this center as a chlorine atom with refined occupancy did not give noticeable improvement in final solution, and the occupancy obtained was less than 1% per one complex unit. At 173 K, a maximum of 0.46 e/Å3 was found at the same location. Selection of crystal data and experimental parameters is summarized in Table , and further details as well as full lists of derived results are listed in Supporting Information.

Calculations and Illustrative Material. Analyses of molecular structure, assembly and packing, as well as the preparation of illustrations, were accomplished using XP, CLAT, and Raster3D program packages. X-ray single-crystal data obtained in this work or taken from the literature were used. Signs of torsion angles were assigned as in ref . The following system of van der Waals radii was applied everywhere:40,41 C 1.71, H 1.16, Cl 1.90, Cu 1.40, F 1.35, O 1.29 Å.

elements.content: Channel profiles were calculated for the β-[CuL2] host matrix by finding the diameter of the largest possible inscribed sphere that is in van der Waals contact with the channel walls as the center of the sphere moves along channel axis. The coordinates of the sphere were (0,0,Z), where Z was a variable expressed as a fraction of the c crystallographic translation. Guest species were removed from atom lists in these calculations. All numerical data used in the calculations are listed in the Supporting Information material.

elements.content: The packing coefficient is defined as a ratio of the volume of all molecules forming the unit cell to the total volume of the unit cell. The volume of the guest molecules was calculated as usual while for the host the total volume of the host matrix per unit cell was calculated (using CLAT37) because of the polymeric nature of the host structure. A full list of calculated volumes and packing coefficients is given in Supporting Information.

elements.content: Isolation of the Crystalline β Polymorph. A new result of this work is that the β polymorph may be prepared as a bulk single-crystal product of good purity and quality (e.g., for storage, kinetic experiments, single-crystal XRD). As opposed to the dense α form, the β polymorph cannot be obtained directly by crystallization, as its micropore volume is open and highly predisposed to solvent entrapment. Usually, inclusion compounds are obtained as crystalline materials, and they contain the β polymeric matrix as the host component. In general, the decomposition of inclusion compounds follows one of two schemes:7,43 The most common way is when guest release causes the host matrix to collapse into a more stable, dense form of the host. A less common way is when upon guest release the empty microporous structure of the host is retained. Although most inclusions of β-[CuL2] decompose according to the latter scheme, the preparation of high-quality crystals of the empty β polymorph is a challenge. The problem for heavy guests is to drive them off at ambient temperature, as heating increases the chances of host matrix collapse, especially when it is necessary to remove residual guest species tightly trapped in long, isolated channels. For volatile guests, the problem is cracking of crystals during the desorption process caused by lattice contraction. The key idea, successfully accomplished in this work, was the very slow decomposition that allows the crystals to relax upon guest removal so that the guest concentration gradient along a crystal channel is very low during the entire process.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Isolation of the Crystalline  β  Polymorph. A new result of this work is that the β polymorph may be prepared as a bulk single-crystal product of good purity and quality (e.g., for storage, kinetic experiments, single-crystal XRD). As opposed to the dense α form, the β polymorph cannot be obtained directly by  crystallization, as its micropore volume is open and highly predisposed to solvent entrapment. Usually, inclusion compounds are obtained as crystalline materials, and they contain the β polymeric matrix as the host component. In general, the decomposition of inclusion compounds follows one of two schemes:7,43 The most common way is when guest release causes the host matrix to collapse into a more stable, dense form of the host. A less common way is when upon guest release the empty microporous structure of the host is retained. Although most inclusions of β-[CuL2] decompose according to the latter scheme, the preparation of high-quality crystals of the empty β polymorph is a challenge. The problem for heavy guests is to drive them off at ambient temperature, as heating increases the chances of host matrix collapse, especially when it is necessary to remove residual guest species tightly trapped in long, isolated channels. For volatile guests, the problem is cracking of crystals during the desorption process caused by lattice contraction. The key idea, successfully accomplished in this work, was the very slow decomposition that allows the crystals to relax upon guest removal so that the guest concentration gradient along a crystal channel is very low during the entire process.

elements.content: The bulk product isolated after decomposition of the methylene chloride inclusion compound still contained cracked crystals, but a few single crystals of excellent quality were obtained. The single-crystal XRD results, as described in a separate section, demonstrate that the crystal studied has the β type structure with preserved but empty micropore space. The phase homogeneity of the bulk product and its correspondence to the single-crystal XRD results are demonstrated in Figure . The solution 1H NMR spectra confirm the chemical purity of the β polymorph obtained, as no residual guest was detected, and confirm the polymorphic relationship between the α form and β form as their solutions exhibited essentially the same spectra.

The phase homogeneity of the bulk product and its correspondence to the single-crystal XRD results are demonstrated in Figure . The solution 1H NMR spectra confirm the chemical purity of the β polymorph obtained, as no residual guest was detected, and confirm the polymorphic relationship between the α form and β form as their solutions exhibited essentially the same spectra.

elements.content: Stability of the Crystalline β Polymorph. The β form is a metastable polymorph of the [CuL2] complex. This conclusion immediately follows from such observations as the eventual transformation of the β form into the stable α polymorph2,3 or the exothermal β → α transition observed in DSC experiments. The intensity of the exotherm indicates that the β form is 1.31(5) kJ/mol thermodynamically less stable than the α form. The main factor contributing to this energy difference is likely to be the packing, as discussed later in this work. The empty β form only exists for kinetic reasons, and it is therefore the kinetic stability that will be discussed at greater length.

The intensity of the exotherm indicates that the β form is 1.31(5) kJ/mol thermodynamically less stable than the α form. The main factor contributing to this energy difference is likely to be the packing, as discussed later in this work. The empty β form only exists for kinetic reasons, and it is therefore the kinetic stability that will be discussed at greater length.

elements.content: The stability limits upon heating of the β polymorph are demonstrated by the DSC method. Figure shows DSC curves recorded for samples of varying crystal size. All four experiments start with the β form, with the α form as product, and the exotherms observed in the region displayed indicate an irreversible β → α phase transition. Thermogram (1) was reported before4 for a powder sample. A high concentration of surface defects likely facilitates nucleation, while the small size of particles causes the entire process to occur over a narrow range, it being complete by 80 °C. Ground, crushed, and as-prepared crystals (thermograms (2), (3), and (4), respectively) exhibit exotherms of irregular form with their maxima shifted significantly to higher temperatures. It can be seen that the actual exotherms begin at ∼70 °C, the same as for the powder sample, but the main effect takes place at a higher temperatures and over a wider range. The explanation for this behavior may be the partial separation of nucleation and crystal growth steps. Heating to ∼70 °C may induce trans to cis molecular isomerization of the [CuL2] units followed by nucleation of a new phase. The second step, crystal growth, requires a time that depends on the size of the crystals and therefore lasts until thermal acceleration compensates for larger crystal size. An exciting result of these experiments is that, being in single crystal form, the β polymorph is observable at temperatures >100 °C. If there were no other, more stable form, it would be thermally stable at this temperature (i.e., without decomposition).

elements.content: The stability of the single crystal β polymorph under ambient conditions (open air and room temperature) is also significantly greater than for the powder. No signs of decomposition were observed for at least six months after the material was prepared, and significant quantities of it survived for 10 months. High-quality single crystals of the polymorph remained intact for nearly a year. As reported earlier, powder samples transformed totally in less than three weeks.

elements.content: Figure shows a photograph of the sample eight months after the β polymorph was prepared. The growing α form shows as a fine-crystalline phase radially dispersing from apparent nucleation centers (indicated by bold arrows) with strongly pronounced interphase boundaries. As a rule, only one nucleation center was observed per crystal, two in rare cases. This fact indicates that nucleation is a limiting step and is responsible for the long survival of the metastable crystals. Again, the slowness of nucleation seems to be related to the kinetic barrier for trans to cis isomerization of the [CuL2] units that is followed by their reassembly. It should be mentioned that for large crystals the time required for crystal growth is comparable to that required for nucleation.

elements.content: A last observation obtained for transforming samples was a “shrinking”, as transparent crystals of the β polymorph transformed into the polycrystalline α form. This observation is in good accord with the experimentally found difference in molar volumes of the phases:  323.12 and 362.1 cm3/mol for α and β forms, respectively. The transformation causes as much as a 10.8% contraction in phase volume.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of the β Polymorph. The main result of the structural study is that the coordination matrix of the empty β form retains the same architecture as in the inclusion compounds studied previously. In other words, the β polymorph does exist as a microporous material even in complete absence of guest.

elements.content: The structure of the [CuL2] unit (Figure ) is largely the same at 293 K and at 173 K. The complex unit is centrosymmetric, and so is trans configured with respect to the ligand substituents. The copper atom has a square-planar environment with two pairs of chelating oxygens from ligand moieties at distances of 1.91−1.93 Å. The entire bischelate fragment is planar within 0.06 Å. The trifluoromethyl group (protruding into the channel) displays increased thermal parameters and is disordered by rotation about the C(12)−C(11) bond (occupancy found for the main orientation is 72(1)% at 293 K and 84.0(8)% at 173 K).

Minor components of disordered fragments are outlined with dashes. Methyl hydrogen atoms are omitted. Square-planar coordination environment of copper(II) is extended to distorted octahedral due to methoxy oxygens from neighboring molecules, O(15B) and O(15C), generated from O15 with (4/3 − x + y, 2/3 − x, −1/3 + z) and (−1/3 + x − y, −2/3 + x, 4/3 − z) operators, respectively.

elements.content: Two additional types of bonding are responsible for the crystal architecture of the framework. Both are realized simultaneously through the same donor oxygen atom of the methoxy-iso-propyl fragment. The first is an intramolecular hydrogen bond to >C−H of the chelate ring; this interaction plays an important role, fixing the molecule in a definite conformation. The second is an intermolecular apical coordination to copper centers of the neighboring [CuL2] units; this interaction builds up the 3D microporous β framework.

elements.content: At 293 K, the methoxy-iso-propyl fragment is disordered over two orientations (Figure ), the occupancy of the main one being 84.9(4)%. The oxygen in the main orientation, O15, is connected to C13 by hydrogen bonding at 2.903(3) Å and coordinated to copper of the adjacent unit at 2.768(2) Å. The oxygen in the minor orientation, O25, is connected to C13 at 2.817(8) Å and to copper at 2.841(7) Å. Thus, the major orientation contributes more strongly to the 3D assembly. The C14−C15−O−C torsion angle equals −55.1 and +52.4° for the major and minor orientations, respectively. Similar disorder was observed in inclusion compounds studied before and will be discussed in the next section. At 173 K, O15 is connected to C13 at 2.905(2) Å and to copper at 2.708(1) Å with a C14−C15−O15−C18 torsion angle of +56.1°. The unexpected result, though, is that at 173 K the disorder disappears. Taking into account that all results were obtained for the same crystal, this means that the disorder has a dynamic component and the relative populations must be thermally controlled. The methoxy-iso-propyl tail is able to rotate, and this seems to be one of the controlling factors that can explain the unique flexibility of the β framework.

elements.content: The β polymorph is trigonal, R-3, with nine [CuL2] units per unit cell (Figure a). Straight, isolated channels stretching along the c crystallographic axis form the micropore space in the structure. Three [CuL2] units surround the channel at one level, connecting to three units on the next level. The inner diameter of the channel varies from 4.8 to 6.1 Å; the inner surface (Figure b) is formed by methyl and trifluoromethyl groups and is complicated by niches.

elements.content: As was reported before, the α polymorph is orthorhombic, Cmc21, with eight [CuL2] units per unit cell. The α polymorph contains similar square-planar [CuL2] units, but only half of them are trans while the other half are cis configured with respect to the ligand substituents. The trans unit possesses the same set of additional bonds while the cis unit has a Cu−F interaction instead of one axial Cu−O15‘ bond. The trifluoromethyl groups are disordered except for the one associated with the additional coordinative bonding. The overall assembly results in a 3D coordination framework but does not display microporosity.

elements.content: The methoxy-iso-propyl fragment of the cis unit is disordered in the α form in a similar fashion as in the β matrix, with the occupancy of the main orientation at 89%. The oxygen of the main orientation, O15, is connected to C13 by hydrogen bonding at 2.834(5) Å and coordinated to copper of the trans unit at 2.804(3) Å. The oxygen of the minor orientation, O25, is connected to C13 at 2.913(9) Å and to copper at 2.702(8) Å. The trans unit, which is asymmetric, has two intramolecular hydrogen bonds at 2.615(6) and 2.846(7) Å and assembles to two adjacent cis units by methoxy oxygen with Cu−O of 2.695(5) Å and a fluorine atom with Cu−F of 3.253(5) Å.

elements.content: Thus, despite drastic changes in isomer composition and overall structural organization, the α and β forms display a similar set of valence bonds and additional interactions resulting in 3D coordination frameworks. The most important factor for the higher stability of the α form seems to be its higher packing efficiency of 56.5% as compared to 50.6% for the β polymorph (Table ). Packing efficiency is a very important factor for molecular crystals, and that was recently demonstrated for other organic and metal-organic supramolecular systems.

Flexibility of the β Matrix. The 3D framework reported in this paper is likely to be the most flexible of all coordination polymers known so far for which the micropore structure is preserved upon guest exchange or removal. Although the basic architecture of the β matrix remains the same, the matrix is flexible, readily adapting its structure to changes in temperature or included guests. The unit cell volume varies from 5262 and 5411 Å3 for the neat β polymorph (at 173 and 293 K, respectively) to 5714 Å3 for inclusion with ortho-dichlorobenzene2 (room T), the expansion being as much as 8.6%. Abrahams et al. have described a 3D coordination framework that is robust enough to allow for reversible guest exchange, yet is flexible as the unit cell volume changes by up to 3% during replacement of guest water with nitromethane (the experiments were performed for the same single crystal). Kepert et al. reported another robust metal-organic 3D framework that survives guest removal, yet is expandable by up to 3.1%34 or 2.5%11 upon guest inclusion. There is one example of a flexible robust structure expandable by ∼9% upon inclusion of guest, but these structures are based on Werner complexes and are governed only by van der Waals forces.
elements.clean_text: Flexibility of the  β  Matrix. The 3D framework reported in this paper is likely to be the most flexible of all coordination polymers known so far for which the micropore structure is preserved upon guest exchange or removal. Although the basic architecture of the β matrix remains the same, the matrix is flexible, readily adapting its structure to changes in temperature or included guests. The unit cell volume varies from 5262 and 5411 Å3 for the neat β polymorph (at 173 and 293 K, respectively) to 5714 Å3 for inclusion with ortho-dichlorobenzene2 (room T), the expansion being as much as 8.6%. Abrahams et al. have described a 3D coordination framework that is robust enough to allow for reversible guest exchange, yet is flexible as the unit cell volume changes by up to 3% during replacement of guest water with nitromethane (the experiments were performed for the same single crystal). Kepert et al. reported another robust metal-organic 3D framework that survives guest removal, yet is expandable by up to 3.1%34 or 2.5%11 upon guest inclusion. There is one example of a flexible robust structure expandable by ~9% upon inclusion of guest, but these structures are based on Werner complexes and are governed only by van der Waals forces.

elements.content: Table gives a summary of parameters for the β framework as found in the neat β polymorph and in five inclusion compounds studied previously. The narrowest and widest parts of the channel change in size by 6.5% in the series, the whole matrix thus “breathing” and adapting its micropore space to changes in temperature and included guest.

elements.content: The changes in the β matrix are evident from two parameters responsible for 3D assembly:  the intermolecular coordination bond Cu−O15B varying between 2.71 and 2.80 Å, and the intramolecular hydrogen bond resulting in a C13...O15 distance variation of 2.89−2.91 Å (Table ). The former parameter indicates directly the strength of the coordination assembly and is especially important. The stronger the coordination assembly, the smoother the channel becomes, while weaker coordination results in more prominent undulations in the channel. The difference between maximum and minimum channel diameters is 0.8−1.2 Å for structures with a stronger assembly and 1.3−1.5 Å for structures with a weaker assembly.

elements.content: Figure compares channel profiles in the empty β form (at 293 K) and inclusion compounds with benzene, tert-butylbenzene and chloroform (for clarity, channel profiles for the β form at 173 K, and for inclusions with n-hexane and tert-butyl alcohol are not shown; they are given in Supporting Information). In all structures, a major widening takes place at 0.3−0.7c and a minor widening at 0.9−1.1c (previously, we referred to these as large and small cavities, respectively). The narrowest passages are located between the wide parts approximately at 0.13c and 0.87c. The size of the wide parts varies, giving to each structure an individual channel shape. Of those shown in Figure , inclusion with chloroform displays the smoothest channel while inclusion with tert-butylbenzene exhibits the greatest undulation. The channel of the empty β form has intermediate characteristics and is very similar to that found for an inclusion compound with n-hexane; this comformationally flexible guest seems to adapt well to the host matrix “as is”. Actually, the inclusion of n-hexane at 173 K causes similar but smaller changes than heating of the empty matrix to room temperature, there being a slight expansion and increased undulation.

elements.content: The ability of the matrix to “breathe”, that is, to expand in space, is understandable as a cumulative effect of several minor adjustments. In the series of seven structures listed in Table , unit cell parameter a varies between 24.111 and 24.495 Å (0.38 Å; 1.6%), parameter c between 10.434 and 10.624 Å (0.19 Å; 1.6%), which gives a variation in unit cell volume between 5261 and 5522 Å3 (4.9%). Spatial analysis suggests that the β matrix in general remains quite stable in the series. The torsion angle C13−C14−C15−O15 varies between 51 and 51.3°; the dihedral angle between bis-chelate fragment and the (ab) crystallographic plane between 65.9 and 67.2°, and the dihedral angle between bischelate fragments of adjacent [CuL2] units between 74 and 75.5°. The most important contributor to the flexibility of the matrix seems to be the additional Cu−O15B coordination. As was mentioned before, the length of the bond varies by almost 0.1 Å, and the bond deviates from an axial position by 9.2−11.8° in the series. A full list of the parameters mentioned is given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Analysis of packing efficiency reveals quite a low volume fraction of total space occupied by the β matrix; as expected, the value is approximately the same in all structures, 50−52% (Table ). This is significantly lower than the 56.5% for the stable α polymorph, but inclusion of guests improves this to 57−61%, providing a total gain in packing efficiency.

elements.content: This work reports on the isolation and stability of the β polymorph of the [CuL2] complex, describes the crystal structure of the β polymorph, and compares these results with those for inclusion compounds of the complex studied previously. To emphasize the novelty of this study, the most important conclusions resulting from this work are summarized below.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

This work reports on the isolation and stability of the β polymorph of the [CuL2] complex, describes the crystal structure of the β polymorph, and compares these results with those for inclusion compounds of the complex studied previously. To emphasize the novelty of this study, the most important conclusions resulting from this work are summarized below.

elements.content:
The microporous β polymorph of [CuL2] complex may be prepared as bulk single crystals of suitable quality for single-crystal XRD study.

Single crystals of the β polymorph are an order of magnitude more stable kinetically than powder samples studied previously (no signs of decomposition for six months for the crystals as compared to complete decomposition in three weeks for the powder).
elements.clean_text:
The microporous β polymorph of [CuL2] complex may be prepared as bulk single crystals of suitable quality for single-crystal XRD study. 

Single crystals of the β polymorph are an order of magnitude more stable kinetically than powder samples studied previously (no signs of decomposition for six months for the crystals as compared to complete decomposition in three weeks for the powder).

elements.content: Single crystals of the β polymorph can survive at temperatures >100 °C for a short time (DSC experiments), and this reveals that its instability at this high temperature is due to its collapse to the more stable α polymorph rather than due to its absolute instability.
elements.clean_text: Single crystals of the β polymorph can survive at temperatures >100 °C for a short time (DSC experiments), and this reveals that its instability at this high temperature is due to its collapse to the more stable α polymorph rather than due to its absolute instability.

elements.content:
Nucleation seems to be the limiting factor in the β → α phase transformation, while crystal growth starts to play comparable role only for β crystals of large size.

The collapse of the microporous β polymorph into the dense α form is followed by a visually observed “shrinkage” in volume of the crystalline samples; the XRD studies suggest a 10.8% molar volume contraction for the β → α process.

elements.content: The 3D coordination framework of the neat β polymorph retains the same architecture as for the inclusion compounds of [CuL2] host. In other words, the β polymorph exists as a microporous material even in complete absence of guest.

elements.content: The channel keeps the same general geometry of alternating sections of larger and smaller width for all structures studied. At the same time, the β framework parameters and the shape of the channel are individually distinct for every structure and are sensitive to temperature and the type of included guest. The original β matrix displays very little change upon inclusion of conformationally flexible n-hexane but makes significant adjustments, including the shape of the channel, to include conformationally rigid molecules.

elements.content: The β framework seems to be the most flexible of all coordination polymers known so far, preserving the micropore structure upon guest exchange or removal. The entire range of change in molar volume for the matrix observed so far is 8.6%. This flexibility is a result of a balance between intramolecular hydrogen and intermolecular coordination bonding that the [CuL2] units display, as well as the rotation of the methoxy-iso-propyl fragment of the ligand.

elements.content:
The packing efficiency of the β matrix is low at 51−52%, but it increases effectively upon inclusion of guest molecules to exceed the value of 56.5% for the dense α polymorph.

<ext-link xlink:href="/doi/suppl/10.1021%2Fcg020016w">Supporting Information Available</ext-link>

Tables of crystal data and details of single-crystal XRD experiment, bond lengths and angles, hydrogen-bonding parameters, anisotropic displacement parameters, and hydrogen atom coordinates for empty β-form of [CuL2] both at 293 K and at 173 K, as well as the crystallographic data in the CIF format. Calculated channel profiles for β-[CuL2] matrix, molecular volumes and packing parameters, unit cell parameters, and selected torsion and dihedral angles for a series of six compounds based on β-[CuL2] matrix (listed in Table ). Figures comparing channel profiles for β-[CuL2] matrix in the pure β polymorph at 293 and 173 K, and in inclusion compounds with n-hexane and tert-butylbenzene. This material (13 tables and 3 figures) is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: Differential scanning calorimetry exotherms corresponding to the β → α collapse of [CuL2] (exo up). Samples of empty β-[CuL2]:  (1) fine powder (8.08 mg); (2) ground crystals (5.60 mg); (3) crushed crystals (8.26 mg); (4) intake crystals (14.2 mg). The preparation and thermogram for (1) were reported in ref . Samples from (2) to (4) were derived in this work.

cln_elements.content: Crystals of microporous β form regrowing into stable α form (eight months after the fresh β-[CuL2] sample was prepared). Apparent centers of nucleation are indicated with bold arrows.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystals of microporous β form regrowing into stable α form (eight months after the fresh β-[CuL2] sample was prepared). Apparent centers of nucleation are indicated with bold arrows.

cln_elements.content: The molecule of [CuL2] as found in empty β-polymorth (293 K). A-labeled atoms are generated through centrosymmetry. Minor components of disordered fragments are outlined with dashes. Methyl hydrogen atoms are omitted. Square-planar coordination environment of copper(II) is extended to distorted octahedral due to methoxy oxygens from neighboring molecules, O(15B) and O(15C), generated from O15 with (4/3 − x + y, 2/3 − x, −1/3 + z) and (−1/3 + x − y, −2/3 + x, 4/3 − z) operators, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  The molecule of [CuL2] as found in empty β-polymorth (293 K). A-labeled atoms are generated through centrosymmetry. Minor components of disordered fragments are outlined with dashes. Methyl hydrogen atoms are omitted. Square-planar coordination environment of copper(II) is extended to distorted octahedral due to methoxy oxygens from neighboring molecules, O(15B) and O(15C), generated from O15 with (4/3 - x + y, 2/3 - x, -1/3 + z) and (-1/3 + x - y, -2/3 + x, 4/3 - z) operators, respectively.

cln_elements.content: Molecular assembly and packing in empty β-[CuL2] (293 K). (a) Projection of the coordination framework along the channel direction (unit cell content). (b) Closest surroundings of the channel presented in van der Waals dimensions (Cu atoms are blue, C gray, H white, F green, O red).

cln_elements.content: Pore diameter profile along z direction for β-[CuL2] structure as found in empty matrix (293 K) (1) and inclusion compounds with benzene (2), tert-butylbenzene (3), and chloroform (4). The profile is outlined by calculating the diameter of the largest possible inscribed sphere that is in van der Waals contact with the channel walls as the center of the sphere moves along channel axis.
